title: Misuse of Insert Earphones during Pure-Tone Audiometry
chief_complaint: I had a tube put in my right ear about seven months ago to fix the fluid, but I haven't noticed much improvement in my hearing. My other doctor said the test showed my hearing actually got worse after the surgery, which is confusing.

problem_summary.onset: Chronic history of Otitis Media (OM); most recent PE tube insertion 7 months ago.
problem_summary.course: Fluctuating conductive loss; reported 'paradoxical worsening' on audiograms following recent PE tube placement.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral history; currently Right Ear is the primary concern.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: History of ear drainage (currently resolved), minimal subjective hearing improvement post-surgery.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient is concerned about the reported worsening of hearing status despite surgical intervention.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: To understand why hearing reportedly worsened and to monitor the status of the PE tube.

history.present_illness: Pre-operative evaluation prior to PE tube insertion in the right ear.
history.otologic_history: History of bilateral chronic OM, greater in right ear.
history.prior_management: Repeated PE tubes in the past.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Moderate conductive hearing loss (CHL) at 250-500 Hz, rising to mild CHL at 1000-6000 Hz. Significant air-bone gaps.

history.present_illness: 2 months post-PE tube insertion in the right ear.
history.prior_management: Otologist noted 'paradoxical worsening' of hearing based on this exam.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Worsening of low-frequency thresholds compared to pre-op, despite functional PE tube. Moderately severe CHL at 250 Hz.

numeric_results.change_from_preop: 20 dB poorer at 250 Hz, 10 dB poorer at 500 Hz

history.present_illness: Follow-up for 'worsening' hearing and PE tube monitoring.
history.otologic_history: Right PE tube in place for 7 months. No recent OM in left ear.
history.prior_management: Otologist adopted 'wait-and-see' approach after V2 results.

tests.name: Otoscopy
tests.key_findings: Right PE tube patent. Left ear normal.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear flat (Type B) with abnormally large ear canal volume, consistent with patent PE tube. Left ear normal.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes absent. Left ipsilateral reflexes present.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Using insert earphones: Right ear thresholds comparable to V2 (poor low-frequency thresholds). Left ear normal.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs in good agreement with PTAs. Word recognition excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Using supra-aural headphones: Significant improvement in low-frequency thresholds compared to insert earphones. Confirms artifact.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a patent PE tube in the right ear and normal hearing in the left ear. Initial testing with insert earphones suggested a worsening of low-frequency conductive hearing loss in the right ear post-surgery. However, re-evaluation using supra-aural headphones revealed significantly better low-frequency thresholds (15 dB improvement at 250 and 500 Hz). The discrepancy confirms that the use of insert earphones in an ear with a patent PE tube (low impedance) resulted in an artifactual loss of sound pressure level in the ear canal, leading to inaccurate 'worse' thresholds.
counseling_points: The 'worsening' of hearing you were told about was actually a measurement error caused by the type of earplugs used during the test.
Because you have a tube in your eardrum, the foam earplugs (insert earphones) let some sound escape or lose energy differently than headphones that sit over your ears.
When we tested you with the over-the-ear headphones, your hearing levels were better and matched what we expect for an ear with a tube.
Your tube is open and working correctly to keep air in the middle ear.
We will inform your ear doctor that your hearing has not actually dropped, so they don't need to worry about other complications.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is confused and slightly anxious because you were told your hearing got worse after a surgery that was supposed to help.
You feel fine physically (no pain, no drainage), which makes the 'worse' test results even more puzzling to you.
Express relief when explained that it was just a testing equipment issue, not a medical failure.
